I started following one of Adrienne's 30-day journey in 2019, and that was when I first fell in love with Yoga. That was when I started to learn about the power of breathing! The physical and mental changes that I experienced at the time was so amazing that after completing the 30 day journey, I decided to continue doing Yoga by myself. And for a long time, life was good.

I am currently back to who I was before Yoga. Basically stressed, depressed, and constantly tired. I stopped doing Yoga a few months so I didn't think getting back into will be difficult. But oh boy, I started Day 1 yesterday and oh my god! Poses that used to feel so easy for me somehow became very very difficult. My legs were shaking and when I woke up today, my whole body is sore! I did not want to continue with this. But guess what, I am not gonna give up cause I will reach to that point in life where I can feel good again!

I know it's a long comment but I really needed to do this and since I don't really have friends that can possibly understand this, I figured the comment sections would have plenty! Stay safe everybody!

Thinking of each breath as a new arrival really clicked with me. I started to think of the breath entering my body as a friend. When you're about to meet a friend, you get excited and look forward to it. And when the friend leaves, you tell them how glad you were to see them. So I started to look forward to each breath, and think "Thank you for the opportunity" to say goodbye to each breath as I exhaled and let it go. I've never been more able to focus on my breath throughout a practice.

I feel very peaceful and grateful for each breath and each opportunity to experience it.

After having a braintrombose in october (bloodcloth to the brain) and finally feeling up to starting a daily yoga practice again yesterday, I'm wondering if any of you know any herbal teas that don't contain licorice. I used to drink yogi tea after practice and throughout the day, but my physician told me to avoid licorice at all costs since that increases blood pressure and thus adds to the risk of having another bloodcloth. I like this class a lot. I was there for day 1 too. I just have a critic I hope is useful.

The speaking is very monotonous, and it becomes stressful when you have to turn your head up to the screen every five seconds to check if you're doing it right, or if you have been holding the pose for too long. I have the feeling that I cant trust this voice that goes "so you tuck your chin to your chest and bring your foot onto the mat AND BRING YOUR ATTENTION TO YOUR BREATH move this to that and roll up to the sky AND THEN THE IDEA OF THE ARRIVAL..." : I mean, you cant just let the flow go and look for the inflection of the voice to follow the instructions, you have to be there for each word, studying what's possibly coming at the end of the sentence so you're not too late doing your move (and if you miss one word - maybe because a car passed or because you're not fluent in english - then you feel totally lost). And whenever the tone changes, it gets your attention, you get all excited about whats coming next, and you realize it wasnt new information, it was just telling you to relax, which has the opposite effect. ^^
I have arrived. I feel grateful. Thank you for your teaching. Namaste!

Day 2 Thoughts:
Yesterday, I started doing this. I had been wanting to, but I kept putting it off because I was making the excuse of "Oh, it's so long. I don't have time" (but I was just sitting on the couch watching YouTube anyways). However, I realized just how much tension I was holding in my jaw (I have TMJ and it's been worse lately) and so I sat down and did the video.
I woke up today, debating on if I wanted to get out of bed early and do this or if I wanted to sleep an extra hour and just do it in the evening. I got up and did it. I'm glad I decided to start my day this way.

Love After Love

The time will come
when, with elation
you will greet yourself arriving
at your own door, in your own mirror
and each will smile at the other's welcome,

and say, sit here. Eat.
You will love again the stranger who was your self.
Give wine. Give bread. Give back your heart
to itself, to the stranger who has loved you

all your life, whom you ignored
for another, who knows you by heart.
Take down the love letters from the bookshelf,

the photographs, the desperate notes,
peel your own image from the mirror.
Sit. Feast on your life.


Derek Walcott

When you said at the very end that every practice will be different, and you might have a moment where you think you won't show up, tears came. This practice has definitely got me feeling that way for future practices. It was especially hard, and somehow the "arrive at every breath" that seemed so wonderful in idea was difficult in practice, and made it harder to just breathe. It didn't help me turn off my thinking brain. I worry that I'm doing too much, and that I'm hurting my body. But I also worry that I'm not doing enough if I modify or just stop doing a certain pose. But every practice will be different. A new beginning. I will try anew tomorrow, even though it is hard, and I will seek to trust myself.

This being human is a guest house. Every morning a new arrival. A joy, a depression, a meanness, some momentary awareness comes As an unexpected visitor. Welcome and entertain them all! Even if theyâ€™re a crowd of sorrows, who violently sweep your house empty of its furniture, still treat each guest honorably. He may be clearing you out for some new delight. The dark thought, the shame, the malice, meet them at the door laughing and invite them in. Be grateful for whoever comes, because each has been sent as a guide from beyond.

I've never commented before, but I started practicing yoga by following your videos sometime last year. It helped me get through the worst moments of isolation and anxiety. I'm commenting today because this particular practice taught me something so new--the concept of arriving with each inhale. As I've continued through the other videos of this series so far, I keep coming back to that. Even when I'm not doing yoga--when I start to get stressed or check out I catch myself inhaling and thinking "arrive" and it's like... a reset button. I come back to myself. And in practice, I use it to bring myself back when my thoughts wander OR to help when I'm meeting my edge and don't think I can keep going. "Arriving" on that next inhale when my body is shaking is for me, again, a reset that lets me feel like I'm restarting the session even if I'm in the middle of it. SO yeah. Thank you so much for all your videos, for your kind and fun attitude. <3

Got really busy and forgot to do yoga yesterday! So I decided to do this video tonight, and man this video has helped me a whole lot. The idea of arriving with every breath has helped me feel more light and it made me feel as if I have the ability to feel safe in my own head. It sounds strange haha. I needed this because I've been dealing with a lot of anxiety since my family and I all ended up having COVID due to my dad being exposed at his work. My anxieties about COVID has made the experience worse, but this video REALLY gave me relief, and it made me feel safe in ways that I haven't been able to the past few days. Most of all it helped me breathe better (I tend to have shallow breathing when I'm panicking or having anxiety). So thank you thank you thank you Adriene! I'm going to do Day 3 tomorrow morning and Day 4 at night when I usually do your videos :))

Hey guys! I live in Bozeman, Montana in the US. This is my first 30 day yoga challenge. I am so excited to be a part of this. I read a comment after I finished day 1 that recommended that I take note of how many views there were when I finished that day's yoga session and then to refresh the video to see how many people were doing the practice at the same time that I was. It was so cool to see that on day 1 I was joining 22,000 other people from around the world doing the same yoga practice. It was so rad!! So today I just finished doing day 2 (I am behind 1 day, but I am being gentle and patient with myself about not having to do it all "perfect" ). The truth is I just practiced yoga with 14,000 other people. So cool!! You should try checking out how many others were doing yoga together virtually with you too :)
Take care, enjoy!! Stacy

I counted the seconds for the pose at 22:16 ... it is 35 seconds. How many breaths are then? 15? But should a pose that gets so much tension really be maintained for so long in yoga? I mean lifting on the tip of your foot, the whole weight of the body on the wrists, the muscle of the one leg high... I love this channel so much but sometimes I get the impression that with the talk the practice loses a bit its yoga flow, and becomes something bodily hard. Not saying that hard is bad, but just that it has to have a dimension of righteousness, and those 35 seconds to me say the opposite.

The concept of "with each new breath a new arrival" took my practice to a new level. For me it was similar to the meditation cue of bringing my awareness back every time I realize my mind has wandered. Day 2 and already profound insights, I'm eagerly looking forward to the next 28! (P.S. Congrats on hitting 9M! The growth is exponential now, it's amazing to observe.)

I love the idea of arriving with every inhale! :)
On the one hand, because when I'm arriving in a pose, I'm checking how my body is, if I need to shift something. And I tend to forget that when I'm holding a pose. But with a new arrival/a new beginning every inhale, I'm checking my body parts, my muscels, my mind every time I inhale and therefore do the exercises more precise and definitely more present :)
And on the other hand, a new arrival at every inhale also means, that I don't need to stay, I can walk away at every exhale. And we agreed that showing up is the hardest part. So what I mean is that I was greatful for myself not only to show up, but also to decide every single inhalte to stay and continue the journey.
Thank you Adriene!

A major goal of mine this year, and with this practice, is to create a more trusting relationship between my mind and my body. I've often felt frustrated and saddened by the ways I've been a stranger to myself but the reminder that each new birth is an arrival encourages me to honor the ways I will continuously be meeting myself.

All of that to say I feel open and emotional and as if I've arrived at a new place with myself. I look forward to seeing where I will arrive tomorrow.

I have two young daughters, and a personal crisis is currently unfolding in my family of origin, so I've been up late the last two nights - after everyone else in the house has gone to sleep - in order to keep this commitment to myself and discover how a daily yoga practice would serve me in a different way than my usual sporadic one. So far, so good! I've felt great following both so far. Yes, it's strange to feel like a bit of a yoga ghost in my own home, but I'm trying to carve out space and time for myself, even if the world won't.
I also unroll my mat after I've put my boys to bed and the house is dark and quiet. Today at stressful moments, I reminded myself I would have this time.... it helped me feel more at ease

I commented on Day 1 about the abrupt end of my toxic relationship and the overwhelming support I received was beautiful. This community is absolutely amazing and thank you for being here for me. Last night, I had to admit my mother into the hospital due to a sudden decline in health. When it rains, its pours. I found myself sobbing the first couple of minutes as I let my emotions release and truly focused on how I felt. 2021 has already presented challenges for me; however, I know despite the current pain it is all going to lead to inner strength. I will continue to remain hopeful and strong. Thank you.

I believe it's a variation of vajrasana. I find it too hard on my feet to curl my toes under so I just uncurl them and sit on my ankles/soles. You might also like to place a yoga block or blanket under your bum if it's hard on your knees to sit all the way down. I hope you had a good practice today :)

If I am having LOTS of pain between my shoulder blades (more toward the right side) during meditation pose. Is there something I can adjust in my posture to fix that? I've done a good amount of internet scouring and have been doing yoga fairly consistently for over a year. Would love to hear if the community has any advice!
@Abby Fenwick thanks Abby! I'll definitely try that.

Hi Julia! I'm assuming you mean pain in the seated meditation pose - I have the exact same issue! Sometimes I find it helpful to place a pillow underneath me so my hips are higher up than my knees. I also often do a sort of cat/cow stretch when I'm seated to give my back a little of a break or even sit against a wall to take some of the pressure off if I really need it. There's also the option of sitting in a chair too! I hope you had a good practice today :)

I felt so present in this practice. For me, arrival is about starting new. With each arrival--each breath--I can deepen a stretch, strengthen my muscles, create a new moment for me and my body. Once I started focusing on my arrival with each breath, I realized that each plank, each cobra, each downward dog, each moment doesn't have to be like the previous. With my arrival, I can be something new; thereby, learn something new. Just in these two days, I can see how the things I learn on my mat will definitely be coming with me off my mat.

For the first time in I don't know how many years, I did not sign up for a mileage based challenge.  I have spent years pushing my body trying to hit 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, and 2020 miles per year.  Every year I do my best and every year I fail to reach the goal.  Throughout the years I've had to overcome pneumonia, knee issues, feet issues, ridiculously long work hours, a head injury, and this year, a torn calf.  The torn calf led me to the Home journey from last year.  Finally I felt peace when I exercised.  After thirty days, my knees, feet, and calf felt better.  The practice didn't aggravate my injured brain.  I didn't have to overcome anything.  I just felt good - not as stiff, stronger, and just better about myself.  So this year, I didn't sign up for any mileage based challenge.  I'm going to focus on yoga and walk three times a week.  I'm going to not push myself through pain.  Imagine that?  I'm going to see what happens when I honor and listen to my body rather than ignore everything it's trying to tell me.  Today was wonderful.  I am no yoga guru.  I still can't sweep my leg all the way through to a lunge but I can get to one and do one pretty darn well once I'm there!  Hahaha.  Each day I do my best and for once, I know that this is enough.  I am enjoying the journey.  Thank you Adrienne.  I am forever grateful for my torn calf because it led me to your page.  <3
So grateful for this practice and resetting my focus for 2021. Thank you!
Ooh yeah, really felt that exhale of the whole YWA community breathing out together in unison! Weâ€™ve arrived!!! ğŸ˜

Technically, I'm all healed up and cleared to do what I want, but am still so stiff and sometimes numb.  Between these two life events and COVID, I've gained a ton of weight, and it's all belly fat.  I think it's the stress, and so when I had the chance to join this 30 days of yoga, I jumped on it.  Granted, I'm on semester break right now, but I still feel so much more relaxed after just two days, and more flexible, too.  Love the focus on breath and new beginnings.  Thanks!

"arrive" is just the theme i needed!! meditation is very challenging and feels unnatural for me, as is simply being "present" - my brain feels like an angry panicked animal that lunges away crazily every time i try to rein it in. so i've always shied away from that kind of mindfulness despite knowing how much it might help. but "arrive" is perfect, because implicit in the idea of "arrive with each breath" is the idea that you might have wandered away in the meantime. the emphasis isn't on staying there, just starting there, getting your foot in the door, over and over and over again. it feels unintimidating and possible. i did this video first thing this morning and i've practiced "arriving" all day - as i load laundry, as i microwave food, as i type this comment. just taking a deep breath and arriving where i am, knowing that it's okay if i float away again a minute later, because i can come back again. i'm so excited to hang onto this word and keep exploring in the rest of this month.

I cannot seem to get Closed Captioning with these sessions. Yes know it seems intuitive that if your face is in mat or eyes closed you cannot read the captions. However through the magic of computers if I feel I am missing something I could rewind and play back. If I cannot understand what you said the first time its doubtful with my type of hearing impairment that listening twice or a thousand times would matter. I am using wireless headphones along with hearing aids. Hearing loss has removed me from many activities that I used to enjoy. I hope that yoga class isn't going on the list with: working as a nurse, live concerts, Movies at a Theater, enjoying a night out with friends, having a normal conversation around the dinner table. All things deafness has irrevocably ruined for me. I'm only 62, hearing aids since age 42.
Hi Sharie, you should be able to toggle the Closed Captioning off/on by clicking the white "cc" box next to the gear in the bottom right corner. Hope that helps!

I have done several of Adriene's 30 day yoga journeys, and this time I have felt resistant at times, almost as if I am resisting the commitment.  I know this is counterintuitive, so  each day's encouragement to "just show up" is so encouraging.  At the start of the practices I am noticing some discomfort in my upper back, despite using a blanket under my hips, and I think I am really paying attention to sitting up straight.  Does anyone else have this issue, and if so, what helps with that discomfort at the beginning?

I have pain in my back when sitting straight and being still for a long time like in the beginning is very difficult. I try to hold it as long as possible (comfortably) and then do small movements (circles/flex/curve spine) to loosen it up if it gets tight/try to relax and then go back to it when it feels better, in the previous 30 day journey I did, it did improve over time and is all about practice. It's good to know your limits and incorporate it in so you don't over do it!

â€œThis being human is a guest house.
Every morning a new arrival.
A joy, a depression, a meanness,
Some momentary awareness comes

THE GUEST HOUSE, By RUMIğŸŒ·

Good to remember that yoga practice is a metaphor for life and sometimes it's a literal reminder: Breathe, show up, be flexible, adapt as necessary, take risks, find balance, take a rest, challenge yourself, notice when you're stressed, notice when you've improved, etc. We just need to know when and how to do any of these things at any moment when we listen to our bodies and minds. I write this not from the point of view of being an expert, but because this is what I'm working on.
Thank you! I've been busy on a laptop and had a lot of pain in my upper back/shoulder. After this practice it's totally gone! I love when you say that each breath is a new invitation to arrive!

Iâ€™m 69 and was diagnosed with osteoporosis so I put my yoga on hold and began to do a lifting class, BodyPump, by Les Mills, at my club. I also started doing BodyFlow, another Les Mills class. It combines Tai Chi moves with yoga and core work. After 4 months I noticed I had developed tennis elbow. it was painful and I had to stop using it for a few weeks. I decided not to do any more BodyPump classes, and am replacing it with yoga once again. I will continue BodyFlow but NO MORE HEAVY LIFTING. Itâ€™s so sad when we work to get fitter only to injure ourselves. Yoga is so much gentler yet still challenges me. Adriene, your class has been a lifesaver during Covid. I know I speak for a lot of people when I say this. I see that you have become much calmer over the years and seem more mature. I wonder if you will decide to go on a sabbatical to India at some point, lol. I love your funny asides or when you sing a song related to what youâ€™re doing or saying. As a musician I often think about doing the same thing but find myself holding back. Why? We should all be feeling free to sing whenever we feel it,  but most of us are too uptight, I guess. Anyway, thanks for being your wonderful free-spirited self and letâ€™s keep doing this for a long long time! SoundCloud: Summerfly,el-and-al

Today I was struck by how arriving in each moment made me forget about whether I was doing something "correctly". I struggle with perfectionism, and this practise made me come to a realisation that in striving for perfection with sacrifice so much. We sacrifice the present moment, and what really exists, rather than savour it, embrace it, and nurture it. Think of all the thing you don't notice because you're think about whteher you're doing something perfectly. I'm making a commitment to arrive at every moment more often.

Remember that it's okay to modify.  If plank pose is too hard, you can do table pose.  Do not worry if you can't do a pose right away.  I've been practicing yoga for 14 years and there are still some poses I can not do.  It's about being present and the breath.   You just keep practicing.  Try the pose a little bit every time you practice.  Modify when you need.  Someday, you might get it.   There are some poses that I can do now that I couldn't do when I first started.  I just laughed like " Ya right, sure!" .   Then one day, I did it!   Just breath, do what you can.  That is all that matters.

Day 2 of practicing with hypermobility (possible and very likely hEDS- a connective tissue disorder which manifests in hypermobile joints (frequent dislocations) and skin, and other symptoms like heart palpitations, digestive issues, chronic pain and fatigue that can be more harm than good when it comes to exercise like yoga, which is often given as a recommendation if you experience chronic pain (as it was given to me when I was told I had fibromyalgia, as no one had noticed my hypermobility), as those with hypermobile joints can very easily overextend these joints or destabalise them, making them feel worse, rather than finding the practice useful and soothing, there's a confusion between flexibility and hypermobility, something I didn't understand for a long time and I'm still getting used to with my new awareness of my symptoms and my joints.))- I'm doing this as not only do I want something to help me bring awareness to my breath, but to my body, and how I can modify practices to make sure I don't cause my body more injury. Today I:
- cried at the very beginning with the 'arrival of breath' and welcoming it etc- yay for emotional release
- halfway through the practice I put my wrist braces on, as I was feeling a lot of pain and strain in them- they're the soft types, without a metal insert. these did help marginally but did hinder putting my whole hands on the ground, and didn't stop strain being put on my fingers as they're only support for the wrists)
- put a blanket under my knees at all times, whether I was in a tabletop position, or straightening my legs to make sure I wasn't overextending or putting stress on my knees. I also in the sitting down forward fold didn't keep my knees on the ground or blanket as I knew I can do that- but in doing so overextending my knees, so I bent them instead to keep them safe)
- tried to be mindful of where my hands were in relation to my shoulders (very difficult), and where my shoulders were in relation to my ribs and neck and ears (weird way to put it but basically- was my shoulder still where my shoulder should SAFELY be, not where it could go if I let it)
- tried to be mindful of always keeping the slightest of bends in the elbow, making sure my elbows didn't over extend
- took frequent breaks, even if it meant I missed a move or two- I know yoga is useful for building strength, but I also kept in mind that pain doesn't always necessarily equal that building of strength, and could mean the move isn't a wise choice for my body
- I can't use my fingers to prop myself up as they're very hypermobile, so attempted to use my whole hand (keeping a slight bend in the elbow) or with my hand in a fist, on my knuckles
- managed the whole session with only one actual pause of the video- whereas yesterday I needed several
all of this was done at the expense of not keeping my thought on the breath at all times, because it's quite a task trying to keep track of everything, but I think I'll keep going with the wrist braces, and keep them in the braces before and after the session, and keep an eye on them, as well as my fingers, elbows and shoulders, which do hurt a bit more than I think they should, especially my fingers, to see if too much stress has been put on them already. If I find they're injured ice and rest shall be applied. I think I did much better than I did yesterday in terms of noticing things I could do to improve my experience, keep my body safe, even if it wasn't exactly how it was instructed, or took away from my awareness of breath, because at the end of the day, can't breathe if the body can't quite breathe with it y'know? I have no clue if anyone will read this or anyone with hypermobile joints specifically will and has any advice or finds this helpful but I was told for YEARS before I knew hEDS was a possibility and I was hypermobile that my chronic pain could basically be cured very magically by exercise- specifically yoga, by doctors and friends and physio and pretty much everyone, and it wasn't until someone noticed I was hypermobile I realised that I was doing myself a disservice because I was overextending everything while doing this exercise, leading to much more pain, and that my body was not compatible with yoga- but I'm attempting to find out if I can MAKE yoga compatible, if I can become aware of which of my joints do what, what symptoms flare during or after, how can I fix that etc.

I think I am finally accepting that, right now, with the current state of my body, I cannot do these yearly 30 day journeys. No amount of props or modifications will make 30 days of very active flows accessible to me at this time. I cried 3 times out of frustration doing day 1 yesterday and today had to skip about 20 minutes of the 37 minute video today, and have had very potent feelings of guilt and anger because the same thing has happened every January the past few years; where I am unable to do these classes and still receive the daily email which just felt like a daily reminder of what I can't do. For the first time, though, thanks to Adriene's guidance, the comments section, and my own growth, I am able to identify all of this. Instead of anguishing that I can't participate in the BREATH journey with ease I am going to pivot and instead commit to 30 days of Adriene's relaxing/cozy/restorative practices. I will be cheering y'all on and joining when I can, but for now I am looking forward to 30 days of gentle yoga <3
good for you!! take your time and go at your own pace ^-^ good luck, I am rooting for you!

Whew. I have found these last two days of yoga challenging. I have been doing Adriene's 30-Day Challenges all through the pandemic. When I read that this year's 30-Day Challenge was "Breath," I was a bit concerned. Sure enough: it has been hard to slooooow down and just focus on the breath. That was always the part I understood and enjoyed the least in previous challenges, eager to just get "started," and move, a little irritated (if I may confess) to be made to slow down. Very interesting. I am sticking with it, and trying to trust Adriene, and trust the process, as she always says. And know that it is probably good for me, if I am feel crabby about it!

Every time Adriene does a 30 days of yoga series, I tell myself I'll do it. But every time, I don't manage it. As soon as I've done the first one, I skip practices, dip in and out, and often just disappear for the whole 30 days and ignore the calendar on my wall. But this time I'm determined to do it! I need to prove to myself that I can commit to something. Both yesterday and today I almost didn't show up. I thought the practices were too long ("how on earth will I fit that into my day?!" *proceeds to scroll on twitter for 2 hours*), and then this one today looked hard. But I gritted my teeth and showed up. (As soon as I made it to the mat it was so fulfilling!) I know that if I want to do it this time, there can be no allowances or skipped days. I need to be here every day.

I know it's only day 2, but I'm really proud of myself for even making it here. And I'm proud of anyone else who has too!

The idea of treating each breath as a new arrival really resonated with me today. Whether it's because of exhaustion or impatience, sometimes these longer videos can be a struggle for me. I get caught up in thinking about how long it's been, what I need to get done today, that I don't have it in me to finish, etc. But by choosing to arrive new, I can think of this time as a collection of valuable moments. I'm not "getting through" the video, I'm continuously beginning something new. And it always helps to use those moments to remind myself that this is the most important thing I'll do for myself all day. Thanks for this one, Adriene!!

Today is honestly a really hard day for me as it marks a sad anniversary. I woke up angry that it's a normal day with things to do because it seems unfair to pretend everything is normal when it's not. Today's "arrive" theme caught me off-guard and I didn't know how much I needed it. After completing the practice I'm starting to accept that I have plans today, and it's not an injustice to keep moving forward. One breath at a time, I can arrive in the present moment, and I can still mourn and honor past events while living my present life. Thank you so much Adriene, and thank you to everyone in this community for doing this practice with me, because today is a lonely day and I'm grateful to have some company.

Reading everyone's comments is like a warm embrace. I have been struggling with body issues lately and to see people with such kind comments saying "we're in this together!" or like "yoga isn't a competition. honor your body, mind, and soul" made me shed a tear. Yoga may be seen as another source to strengthen the body but people forget that it also strengthens our mind, heart, and soul. To be honest, it is rare to find good yoga videos that help us relax, meditate, and be present. Most of the time it is for "vigorous" exercises or simply sequences to just do the poses, never attending to our minds and feelings. I know it's just  a matter of preference but I feel like people should also take the time to be mindful of our thoughts not just do chaturangas and whatnot. This is a biased comment but I do hope people rlly spare time to notice their feelings and thoughts than their physical actions. Im truly grateful for YWA and its community. They teach us to honor our feelings whilst doing yoga. I love that!! sorry if sound pretty demanding I would consider myself bad at expressing myself but I hope my intentions are clear ğŸ˜… have an awesome 2021!!

day 2
jan 2, 2021
11:29 PM
---- ğŸŒ----
Today's practice was an eye-opener. I realized what my problem really was: "stuck and dwelling in the past". Back in early 2020, I exercised daily, did yoga daily, ate healthy foods, drank plenty of water until more food and celebrations came in. I realized how ungrateful i was. I didn't see them as blessings. I saw them as objects that "ruined" me, things that would make me "fat" and "unhealthy" when in fact, it was just the feeling of guilt. I didn't want to admit that I enjoyed the delicious food. And then I stopped doing my daily habits, came the mental break downs and such. I hated myself. "Why can't I be the way I was before? I was smaller and prettier" I tried exercising again but the thoughts of failing just came back. I was so invested in the past and what my imaginable future could look like that I didn't realize where I truly was, the present moment. It made me so lost. so It was my resolution for the new year's to go back to my old ways. Little did I actually know, those old ways were self-destructive. I only wanted to go back to my old ways to look "prettier" This practice really reminded me that it is not to go back to old ways and to embrace the present moment and breathe in for a new start. NEW START. I was so deep in the past. An exit was not to be found. but this practice made me escape. Thank you Adriene for giving me a door to open and ARRIVE in my new beginnings. Much love from the Philippines!

It's absolutely true that showing up is the hardest part and for sure it's hard for me to find that motivation every single day. Here's a tip that I sometimes use to make myself commit to those 'hard' things like showing up for yoga or doing daily piano practice, for example. That is - just roll out your mat / sit down and decide to do 5 minutes. Literally just five minutes. Most likely you'll keep going and do the whole thing, but lets say it really isn't your day and everything is too hard - worst case you've done 5 minutes of breathing and neck rolls or 5 minutes of scales (or whatever). How bad is that? Of course it's not perfect but even 5 minutes is better than nothing at all. Hope that helps! x

@Vicky HK

This being human is a guest house.

Every morning a new arrival.

A joy, a depression, a meanness,

Some momentary awareness comes

As an unexpected visitor.

Welcome and entertain them all!

Even if theyâ€™re a crowd of sorrows,

Who violently sweep your house

Empty of its furniture,

Still, treat each guest honorably.

He may be clearing you out

For some new delight.

The dark thought, the shame, the malice,

Meet them at the door laughing,

And invite them in.

Be grateful for whoever comes,

Because each has been sent,

As a guide from beyond.



THE GUEST HOUSE, By RUMI

The reminder to "arrive" is one I also read recently in a technique for grounding when you're experiencing acute anxiety. You quietly tell yourself your name, what time it is, where you are, and that you are okay. It's like arriving at calm in the midst of chaos. Locating that spot even when I'm feeling uncertain about sensations or postures during the practice is helpful. ğŸ’–

Hi Everyone! A beginner in Yoga. I decided to sign up to Challenge myself to pick up a new hobby! As Adriene says my biggest challenge will be showing up.... However, I'm going to commit to the hr. at most each morning in January. Challenge Accepted!

The Guest House by Rumi

This being human is a guest house.
Every morning a new arrival.

A joy, a depression, a meanness,
some momentary awareness comes
As an unexpected visitor.

Welcome and entertain them all!
Even if theyâ€™re a crowd of sorrows,
who violently sweep your house
empty of its furniture,
still treat each guest honorably.
He may be clearing you out
for some new delight.

The dark thought, the shame, the malice,
meet them at the door laughing,
and invite them in.

Be grateful for whoever comes,
because each has been sent
as a guide from beyond.

â€” Jalaluddin Rumi, translation by Coleman Barks (The Essential Rumi)

Wow! I have been inspired by you to build my daily yoga practice now for the past five years ever since I believe what was your first 30 day challenge and today just blew me away even more than ever, which at this point I didn't think possible! For the past year I have been focused on building my soul biz, The Joyous Parent yes, in the middle of a pandemic and have had so much self doubt, uncertainty, shame for having "abandoned" my fellow educators in the classroom and moving around with a lot of proving energy and fear of failure. But today, when you said to simply celebrate a new beginning with each breath, I was finally and miraculously and simply able to just drop into the amazing miracle and overflowing gratitude of the wonder of what I get to do each day, even each moment. I got to the point by the end of this video that each breath was like "wow, how amazing is my life!" "Wow, I'm so blessed" "wow, this moment is full of so much magic and glory too!" - and I realized, what a gift, if I am able to approach my biz building like THAT, then imagine how much more impact my work and passion will be for others because I will just be in celebration mode of the every amazing, beautiful, imperfect, terrifying moment of putting myself out there and embracing what comes back... I feel able to take the lessons on the mat off of it and into real life on a whole new level. And who knows what will be?! Maybe I just get to be me in this moment, and now in this moment again, and in every moment I say thank you thank you thank you for the gift of this new breath and hello to what might be and become! So thank you. From the bottom of my hear and the top of it and ALL the parts of it. Thank you!!

Had to look up the poem Adriene mentioned. Perfect for today and a good reflection for every day.

THE GUEST HOUSE

This being human is a guest house.
Every morning a new arrival.
A joy, a depression, a meanness,
some momentary awareness comes
as an unexpected visitor.

Welcome and entertain them all!
Even if they are a crowd of sorrows,
who violently sweep your house
empty of its furniture,
still, treat each guest honorably.
He may be clearing you out
for some new delight.

The dark thought, the shame, the malice.
meet them at the door laughing and invite them in.
Be grateful for whatever comes.
because each has been sent
as a guide from beyond.

â€” Jellaludin Rumi,
translation by Coleman Barks

@Elizabeth Weinstein Yes, I am in central New York ( near Greene, NY) and it is cold in the early am.  Started off with wool longs and sweats and a wool sweater.  Had to shed after 20 minutes.  Where in NY?

Yes my house is 55 degrees F when I get up in the early morning, in Central New York. Keep your socks on, wear your bathrobe and pajamas, or a fleece.   Last summer I discovered that I could wear my cheap swimming shoes (dime store stretchy things with a flexible rubber soul) over my socks so my feet will stick on the mat! Whatever makes it work!

I'm happy again to join your 30 day challenge. I just came across with your video Yoga For Complete Beginners - 20 Minute Home Yoga Workout just last year. I have congenital heart problems, started having chest pains and uncontrollable high blood pressure. I was looking over youtube to help me out with my condition.I have no idea about yoga practice. Since I started following you, I managed to go to my mat and practice yoga everyday and I'm happy to say I finished two of your yoga challenges. My blood pressure is getting better and stable and chest pains are easing up.You are such an inspiration and you have motivated me a lot. Since then it's a second nature for me now to practice yoga everyday. I always go to my matt every morning. I wanted to thank you for being such a motivator and a brilliant teacher. More power and stay safe.

The past two months have been my longest break from yoga in two years, then the last week was extremely difficult because my cptsd somehow got triggered and I had a major breakdown followed by nightmares every single night. I feel so lost and broken, but I am trying to believe that I deserve to be found. This is what this year's journey means to me, a leap of faith. It is hard to have faith in myself and it is hard to show up because I feel rusted. But it helps so much to know that I am not alone in this. If I wouldn't have felt the support of this global community of amazing people, I couldn't find the motivation to get back on the mat.

So I just wanted to thank everyone here and share my love ğŸ’™ And thanks to you Adriene for making this possible, for your kind guidance, and for your inspiring grace ğŸ™

The Guest House - Rumi

This being human is a guest house.
Every morning a new arrival.

A joy, a depression, a meanness,
some momentary awareness comes
as an unexpected visitor.

Welcome and entertain them all!
Even if theyâ€™re a crowd of sorrows,
who violently sweep your house
empty of its furniture,
still, treat each guest honourably.
He may be clearing you out
for some new delight.

The dark thought, the shame, the malice,
meet them at the door laughing,
and invite them in.

Be grateful for whoever comes,
because each has been sent
as a guide from beyond.
The poem was given to all new graduates of medicine in Scotland. Love from Israel.

2020 has been my year of hell. After more than 7 years of struggling in my studies and work, I decided to listen to my body and STOP. What followed was of course a breakdown of my body and I was diagnosed with severe, pent up, burnout. I have lain in bed for weeks. Then the pandemic happened. During those weeks in bed thinking, a lot of unresolved childhood trauma caused by skipping grades in school came up. Then, last december, in the space of just 10 days, my grandma died, my dog died and my father, not yet 60 years old, was diagnosed with terminal cancer. I spent NYE sobbing my heart out. What was supposed to be my year of healing dug my even more into the mud.

My former strong and fit body has been reduced to a quivering mess with VERY tight muscles and more than once I had to stop today because it was too hard or because relaxing caused me to sob again. But I am determined to make it through, however many breaks and modifications it might take. Showing up, every day, to do something for myself in these mountains of grief. Healing in 2021 is my goal. Namaste ğŸ§¡

This was a tough one if you're not in full health or have injuries. So remember yoga is for health. It's not an exercise or competition.  Poses are shown with variation and props.  So I do mountain pose instead of plank. With downward dog I use my bed, to put the arms on. If this is hard, use a table. For lunges,  you can either have the stretched leg on the floor. You can also do warrior one. With changes I could do the whole program today too. Now I have breakfast and then I rest. Take care and have lovely sunday.
Take care!

Yeah me to and if I can't hold a pose because I don't want to strain myself  I return to child pose or modify pose.
